title.narrative: Support to Territorial Administrative Reform STAR 3
Support to Territorial Administrative Reform STAR 3

description.narrative: Denna insats stöder, via en förvaltningsfond med flera bidragsgivare, implementeringen av den territoriella administrativa reformen i Albanien genom förbättring av tillhandahållande av tjänster och insyn i kommunala beslut och utgör den tredje fasen av programmet “Stöd till administrativa och territoriella reformer”. Fonden administreras och implementeras av FN:s utvecklingsprogram (“UNDP”) i Albanien, i nära samarbete med Albaniens regering. I denna tredje fas kommer projektet att anta en modulär strategi där fokus och prioritet kommer att läggas på de nyckelaktiviteter som följer av STAR2: nämligen att utvidga OSSIS-nätverket till att omfatta administrativa enheter; främja deltagarstyrning och utvidga antagande av integritetsplanering; öka statlig och lokal förvaltningskapacitet avseende standardisering och insamling av lokala data genom utbyggnad av det nationella integrerade planeringssystemet för informationssystem (”IPSIS-systemet”) på lokal nivå för att kunna planera och övervaka resultat; och genomföra samarbete med den albanska skolan för offentlig förvaltning för tillhandahållande av standardkursplaner för lokala myndigheters personal. I enlighet med dess tillämpningsområde kommer STAR3 att arbeta i partnerskap och nära samarbete med flera offentliga kontor och byråer. Inrikesministeriet kommer att utgöra den högsta nivån av partnerskap, eftersom denna institution har det övergripande mandatet och en tillsynsroll när det gäller de strategiska, operativa och övervakande ramar inom vilka de lokala myndigheterna verkar. Programmet kommer att ha ett nära samarbete med specialiserade statliga organ t.ex. Albaniens myndighet för leverans av integrerad service (“ADISA”) avseende antagande av nationella standarder och gemensamma kontor för tillhandahållande av tjänster. Andra framstående offentliga institutionspartners inkluderar Albaniens nationella myndighet för informationssamhället (“the National Agency for Information Society”), justitiedepartementet, avdelningen för allmän förvaltning och kommissionären för översyn enligt förvaltningslagen, och den nationella myndigheten för bostäder och fastighetsregistrering (“the National Cadaster Agency”). Inom projektet kommer man också att samarbeta med lokala civila organisationer för att undersöka om framsteg görs och främja en debatt om lokala förvaltningsfrågor genom ökat medborgarengagemang och för att undersöka vilken efterfrågan som finns på gräsrotsnivå på lokala åtgärder. Projektet kommer att säkerställa att de lokala organisationer som engageras representerar specifika målgrupper, särskilt kvinnor, sårbara och marginaliserade. Projektet kommer att skapa utrymme för och bjuda in lokala myndigheter och förvaltningar för att utnyttja deras kapaciteter och nätverk i syfte att ytterligare stärka dessa funktioner. Den modulära strategi som byggts upp under utformningen av programmet kommer att göra det möjligt att snabbt genomföra andra specifika aktiviteter om ytterligare resurser erhålls.

This intervention supports the implementation of the territorial administrative reform in Albania through service delivery improvement and transparency of municipal decisions, being the third phase of the Support to Administrative and Territorial Reform programme, designed as a multiple/donor trust fund, administered and implemented by UNDP Albania, in close cooperation with the Government of Albania. . In this third phase, the project will adopt a modular approach, keeping into the focus as priority interventions only the key activities to be followed from STAR2, namely, expanding the OSSIS network to administrative units, promoting participatory governance and expanding the adoption of integrity planning, increasing central and local government capacities on standardization and collection of local data through the expansion of IPSIS system at local level to plan and monitor the performance, and collaborating with Albanian School of Public Administration for the provision of standard curricula for local government staff. In accordance with its scope, STAR3 will work in partnership and close collaboration with several public offices and agencies. The Ministry of Interior will be the highest-level partnership and project counterpart, as this institution has the overall mandate and oversight role on the strategic, operational, and monitoring frameworks where local governments operate. The programme will collaborate closely with specialized state agencies (like ADISA) on adopting national standards and joint single offices for service delivery. Other prominent public institution partners include National Agency Information Society, the Commissioner on Freedom to Information and Data Protection, the Ministry of Justice, Department of Public Administration and the Commissioner for Oversight of the Law on Civil Service, and National Cadaster Agency. The project will also engage with local civil society organizations in reviewing progress and promoting debate on local governance matters, promoting civic engagement and bottom up demand for responsive local action. The project will ensure that engaged CSOs represent specific target groups, especially women, vulnerable and marginalized ones. The project will make space and invite the engagement of the Local Government Associations, making use of their capacities and networks and aiming to strengthen these capacities further. The modular approach built in the design of the programme will enable other specific activities to be triggered in case of additional resources.

sector.narrative: Decentralisation and support to subnational government

tag.narrative: 16.6 - Bygga upp effektiva och transparenta institutioner med ansvarsutkrävande på alla nivåer.

Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative:
CONCLUSION ON PERFORMANCE 1.1 Objectives of the intervention STAR3's overall objective is to strengthen local government effectiveness and efficiency through enhancing the supporting framework, consolidating systems, standards, and organizational capacities in place, expanding, and sustaining service delivery innovation and best practices, and institutionalizing local government accountability to women and men for enhanced participatory governance. The overall objective is supported by the following specific objectives: 1. Local government participatory governance practices are in place and functional and encourage civic engagement. 2. Municipal systems and standards are enhanced, expanded, and consolidated for improved service delivery and overall municipal performance. 3. Government institutions, responsible for decentralization and local government, are capacitated to effectively drive policy development, coordination, and monitoring. 1.2 Examples of results achieved The expected results of the intervention are the following: 1. Methodology for public consultation and participation adopted and implemented in six municipalities and endorsed as a municipal standard. 2. 1/3 of Albanian municipalities supported to adopt integrity planning as a tool for the management of corruption risks. 3. The one stop shop system functionality is improved overall and extended to up to 240 municipal administrative units. 4. A local government data hub, inclusive of local level IPSIS module requirements is in place. 5. Central level government structures in charge of Decentralization and Local Government are capacitated to monitor the implementation of the National Crosscutting Strategy on Decentralization and Local Governance and its Action Plan. When it comes to the implementation on the ground, the early part of the 2021, has been spent to secure the funding of the most important activities, especially those that belonged to the category of those requiring consolidation like the OSS (One Stop Shop); and to build upon the results of the bridging phase between STAR 2 and STAR 3 for a well-targeting and resource-matched Work Plan. Also, the project needed to establish its implementation team. The essential expert project staff has been retained from the Preparatory Phase and moved to the STAR3 project. Nevertheless, during the early bridging phase, the project replaced the OSS expert, as the former one left, and had also to replace the Communication and the Administrative Assistant. Between January March 2021, the project re-hired ten regional coordinators. The staff vacuums were mainly caused by the time gap between the phases of the project. The insecurity of funding and the efforts required for the reestablishment of the project staff team, have contributed to a rather slow start of activities. During the first year of implementation the project has: -developed Terms of Reference for Public Consultation and Participation at local municipality level. - prepared Terms of Reference for expansion of Integrity Planning pilot experience in the selected municipalities. The Activity is about consolidation and expansion of the integrity instrument to at least an additional 14 municipalities, that is making integrity planning a standard and integral part of the overall management of the local administrations in a total of 20 municipalities (1/3 of all Albanian Municipalities). The practice will also be disseminated to other municipalities and the objective is to trigger a positive reaction from additional municipalities by the end of the project. Also, UNDP has engaged a short-term consultancy for the development of various alternatives of an Integrity Index, a quantification measure of the municipal integrity performance, a novelty that the Project envisages to introduce. -an IT needs assessment for OSS expansion in the administrative units has been carried out by the project staff, instead of hired consultantsand as suggested by Sida/Embassy. The assessment has identified approximate needs in consultation with respective Mayors or municipal managerial staff. This exercise was followed up by accurate specifications and formalization of the commitment of each municipality through the signing of MoU-s with the respective Mayors. Larger municipalities have tended to accept and adopt the system in order to increase their performance and service delivery quality. Small and medium municipalities have been more resistant to change, believing that they could serve better and faster to citizens without the system due to their size and service procedures they have followed by years. Differences also vary from one individual to another due to the mentality, experience, and ability to use new technologies. Since the use of OSS has had fluctuations caused by internal leadership issues and outer environment, the project has responded by restoring the OSS Information System maintenance and support services for 48 municipalities until end 2021, improve the connection with the central data systems and refresh the training for the personnel using the system. Public awareness on the benefits of using the OSS has been prepared and conducted. The project has also advanced in the preparations for the rolling out of the OSS in the administrative unit of the target municipalities. -When it comes to Integrated platform for municipal performance /IPSIS, the project has followed and supported the relevant actors (Municipalities and Ministry of Interior) to take a final decision with regards to the approach to be applied in building the system. The options are two: 1) the development of a publicly or semi-publicly accessible integrated platform for local data and indicators, including data and indicators developed by the existing data collection platforms built by existing assistance programmes (Swiss in particular). This would become a centrally run system for data collection on municipal level to be used for statistics and monitoring of performance. The option 2) is about developing and rolling out the IPSIS on local /municipal level. The decision will direct the types of activities to be carried out by the project in this particular area. - with regards to Central level monitoring and reporting capacity building, the project has helped the Ministry of Interior's Local Affairs Directorate to carry out the first round of monitoring of the implementation of the its Action Plan for 2020. 1.3 Assessment of the likelihood that the objectives will be achieved by the end of the intervention given the overall risk Even though initially under-resourced compared to the ambitions, the project has developed realistic plans by adjusting to the changing circumstances at both local and central level. Now that the main bulk of the funds is disbursed from EU and there are promising signs a that USAID might reengage with support to STAR 3, it is expected that the implementation will get a boost in 2022. Especially, if COVID related restrictions will be reduced, it is expected that the effectiveness of the intervention will also increase visibly. One new emerging issue is the ongoing discussion between the two main political parties for a remaking of the territorial division between the municipalities of the country. In case that is going to happen, there might be effects on the STAR 3, as attention will go to the new territorial division. However, since the current phase of the project has been very focused, it is still likely that the results expected can be achieved at the end of the implementation period. 1.4 It is likley that the objectives of the intervention will be achieved No risks have been identified that require monitoring or mitigation by Sida
1.6 Current dialogue issues The possibility for a renewed territorial division needs to be considered during the dialogue with the Ministry of Interior, municipalities targeted by STAR 3, and on political level from the Embassy in the meetings with the leaders of the main political parties. Any new division should ideally lead to better administration of land and human resources at local level and should not compromise the move towards further strengthening of the municipalities. 1.7 Follow-up of dialogue issues The dialogue with the implementing partner and main beneficiary has led to a more vitalized implementation of the intervention, has brought important discussions in the Project Steering Committee and has generated a more coordinated donor feed-back to UNDP and GoA. 1.8 Follow-up plan for the coming period During 2022 the possibility of a revised Territorial and Administrative Reform and its effects on the planned activities of the STAR 3 project needs to be followed up rigorously. Also, important will be to follow up the pending decision about how to approach the data collection system for the local governments. This is a decision that has multiple interests and actors involved and needs to be taken in a way that serves at the same time to the local municipalities and the central government. Also, the use of possible additional funding to the project by rejoining partners like USAID, needs to be connected to the highest next priorities and discussed widely in the PSC meetings. A coupling at least with the Swiss cooperation team for assessments and dialogue about STAR 3 performance and strategic orientation is considered important and useful to the project and will be conducted whenever possible, with the view to achieve a broader donor harmonization in the framework of the intervention.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
